UI_visible_response: The Gang of Four played a pivotal role in the Chinese Cultural Revolution, shaping its policies and direction, and controlling the media and propaganda outlets2. They were an alliance of four leading Chinese politicians who promoted the Cultural Revolution and wished to keep the totalitarian policies of Mao3. The group manipulated the youthful Red Guards and controlled areas such as intellectual education, basic theories in social sciences, and teacher-student relations7. They utilized propaganda, mobilization of youth through Red Guards, and enforcement of radical policies to maintain their power during the Cultural Revolution8. Their influence was particularly strong in the fields of propaganda and cultural affairs, contributing to a dry and dogmatic rigidity in these areas1. After the death of Mao Zedong, Jiang Qing, a member of the Gang of Four, plotted a coup d'état to take power, but she and her close associates were arrested and put on trial9. The Gang of Four aimed to maintain Mao's leftist ideology and policies, placing ideology above the economy, even at the cost of keeping China and its people poor10.
traffic_visible_response: The Gang of Four played a pivotal role in the Chinese Cultural Revolution, shaping its policies and direction, and controlling the media and propaganda outlets [[2]]. They were an alliance of four leading Chinese politicians who promoted the Cultural Revolution and wished to keep the totalitarian policies of Mao [[3]]. The group manipulated the youthful Red Guards and controlled areas such as intellectual education, basic theories in social sciences, and teacher-student relations [[7]]. They utilized propaganda, mobilization of youth through Red Guards, and enforcement of radical policies to maintain their power during the Cultural Revolution [[8]]. Their influence was particularly strong in the fields of propaganda and cultural affairs, contributing to a dry and dogmatic rigidity in these areas [[1]]. After the death of Mao Zedong, Jiang Qing, a member of the Gang of Four, plotted a coup d'état to take power, but she and her close associates were arrested and put on trial [[9]]. The Gang of Four aimed to maintain Mao's leftist ideology and policies, placing ideology above the economy, even at the cost of keeping China and its people poor [[10]].
